description:
Pteronotus mesoamericanus is a species of bat belonging to the family Mormoopidae. It is found in parts of Central America, including Mexico, Guatemala, Belize, and Honduras.

This bat species is relatively small, with a wingspan typically ranging between 30-35 centimeters. Its fur coloration is generally dark brown or black, with a distinct pale-colored throat and belly. Pteronotus mesoamericanus is known to roost in caves, abandoned buildings, and other sheltered locations.

The species is considered insectivorous, feeding primarily on moths, beetles, and other flying insects. It uses echolocation, a biological sonar system, to navigate and locate its prey in the dark environments it inhabits.

Pteronotus mesoamericanus plays an important role in the ecosystem, contributing to the control of insect populations and serving as a food source for larger predators. Its conservation status is currently classified as Least Concern by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), although local populations may face threats from habitat loss and disturbance.
